posts.custom_user_title: 3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design

posts.cooked: What do you mean by “can’t access any kind of planetary gearbox”? If you mean you don’t have the funds to buy it, you are probably out of luck. Creating a custom gearbox is not an easy task and realistically, if you are asking how to make one, it’s probably too late into the build season to be thinking about it. Your best option would be to buy something like the REV MaxPlanetary kit with 3 4x cartridges, or the AndyMark sport gearbox .

Rev EU does appear to be out of stock right now, other import options will likely take even more time.

@Blobbiey What are your space limitations?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
four:

Rev EU does appear to be out of stock right now, other import options will likely take even more time.

Very likely so.  Seems that REV is out of luck at present, though filling in an email and hitting “Notify me” should help them know what to stock better next time.

I think OP has a few options:

Cut the feature and focus on other development work for the in-season events.

Design and build a spur gearbox.  This will require some custom machining access, at least for plates and spacers.  Use a 14T AndyMark pinion gear from the KoP drivetrain (fairly common, surely you can find one over there), and 18 and 80 tooth gears in stock at REV Europe, and you can get 25.4:1 out of two stages.  Add a chain reduction, and 64:1 is achievable.

Reduce weight out of the robot or hanging system, so you can achieve acceptable performance out of less reduction.

At this stage of the game, I find zero fault in going with option 1 and making hanging development an off-season endeavor.

BrookeF:

don’t forget Versaplanetary!

I will.  They were revolutionary a decade ago, but time has passed them by as power levels have risen, select components (like the CIM adapter) have vanished, and new splines have created compatibility issues.  I wouldn’t put anyone running them on a “do not pick” list, but I don’t think I would get a new team started on them.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
The main difficulty you have right now is getting the gearboxes in before your first event…

The challenge is that you need a 64:1 reduction* that works with a NEO. There’s a few ways to do that, mind you–let’s zoom out for a bit.

There’s several ways to get a 64:1 reduction, depending on space available and exact methods. For example, you could use chain or belt to do it; planetary gearboxes are pretty common as well. Spur gearboxes (like the KOP transmission) can do that but it takes a bit of finesse.

The catch? It needs to be a 2-stage reduction unless you get a rather specialized gearbox. (Typical maximum ratio for a 1-stage gearbox or belt or chain is 10:1.**)

I haven’t seen your robot’s geometry, but here’s a few options: a) Timing belt and pulley, 2-stage, 8:1 into 8:1. Probably the quickest option would be to set up a belt-and-pulley system with the output of the first stage driving the pinion of the second. I say “quickest” because you can 3D print those, and the particularly sneaky will make ONE part for the middle shaft. b) Sprocket and chain, 2-stage, 8:1 into 8:1. Same as the timing belt but with your choice of chain and sprockets. (See also: 330) Also pretty quick, but I wouldn’t 3D print this one. c) Spur gearbox, 2-stage, 8:1 into 8:1. This one’s a good bit more compact, but with the smaller size comes stiffer requirements. For one thing, you’ll need to build two plates (rather than potentially running a shaft through a tube) that probably aren’t identical, and have bearings mounted in them, and have standoffs. You’ll need gears; you’ll need to line the gears up correctly in the box (center-to-center). If you’ve got a CNC router or similar, it’s doable. But it won’t be as easy as the other options. OTOH, it’ll be exactly what you need most likely.

*NOT gearbox, but overall gear reduction–at least, that’s what I’m reading. If you need a further reduction, add onto the end of whatever reduction you’re using. **I did say “typical” maximum ratio. If you can find a harmonic or cycloidal gearbox that’s 64:1 and fits a NEO, that’ll be one-stage. Good luck with that, though–those are expensive!
